comment: American Whiskey Advent Calendar, Dec. 1: Caramel with cream on the nose - my mother-in-law's Thanksgiving sweet potatoes (sugar, nuts, toasted marshmallow).  :-)  Smokey and sweet with a little dark fruit on the finish.

Being relatively new to the world of whiskey has probably allowed me to really enjoy this single malt. I'm not persuaded by where it's from or which distillery is producing it. I dont care how long they have been in business or that it's from Waco; a place better known for a crazy cult and a college football team that refuses to play defense. What I can say is that it's exceptionally balanced and bodied. There is a bit of sweetness but that gently fades upon the finish. A really great 'Murican Whiskey. Give it a shot.
Sweetness in the nose with a strong oak character. Remarkably smooth for such a high proof.
There are some interesting flavors going on here. Unfortunately, the high alcohol content doesn't allow them to linger to full effect. This would probably be great at closer to 80 proof.
Yeeeehawww! This one will take you for a ride. Smoke on the nose, wood on the palate, and toasted peanuts on the finish. I enjoyed this more than expected.

There is an overwhelming maple syrup nose.  Dare I say even kind of breakfast smelling.  But once this bourbon hits your tongue it is full bodied Texas BBQ in liquid form.  Moving past the smoke I get a pear lingering with a good mouth feel.  Not overly oily, but it does coat the mouth well. Finish is good slightly hot.  A few drops of water can mellow out the heat.
Smoky, barbeque smells gives way to an equally smoky and malty taste.  With ice, there's a substantial fire and burn, almost like chillies.  I'd recommend without ice...but, it's strong at its ABV.

Even though Chip Tate was unceremoniously disconnected from Balcones,  this is an excellent whiskey. Super unique with a ton of flavor. Amazing what can be done in non-traditional areas by distillers with determination and talent.  Like an excellent single malt with no smoke and a nice malt finish
Great whisky. The higher abv gives it a nice kick but isn't boozy. It tastes like dark chocolate covered cherries, but in a good way.
Well done, Texas! This was a surprising note from west Texas, & the flavor is big, full, & tasty. Very woody, with a bit of dried fruit & nut @ the end.
Caramel, sweetness from the wood, and a tin of heat.  A nice malty back end as it cools.  Still, this is not executed all that well.  A nice novelty, but the high alcohol content numbs your tongue
It's better in taste than one star; however, I'm giving it one star because at the price point there are so many single malts that are much better.
Thick, flavorful, and rich with great legs. Starts with butterscotch, moves to wood, finishes with coffee.

Give this 10 to 15 minutes in the glass to open up. Try it without water first and then slowly add some, bit by bit until you hit your sweet spot.  This was powerful with alcohol due to the high proof but the flavor was powerful and just amazing.  Rich, with deep fruits like a sherried scotch.  Delicious light smokey flavors, maybe from the barrel char?  Sweet vanilla hits and some caramel like a very rich creme brulee or flan.  This has become one of my favorite whiskies.  Who knows where the taste will go now that they've removed the original creator/distiller but up to this point the whisky is fantastic.  Well worth the try if you can find a bottle.

Sophisticated flavor. Underrated here.  Drops of Water open up a smoky nose, converting into Creamy vanilla, orange peel, coffee (or is it tobacco?).  A very pleasant un-peated smokiness at the finish. Little bit of pepper on the end also. Unique& highly recommended if you can find a bottle.
This has a really nice, full bodied flavor that has a lot of depth.  Roasted cherries and malt are front and center.  Highly recommended.
Smell.  Slightly smoky,  oak nose. Spicy,  leathery.  Short finish
Nose: Banana bread, honey, and sweet spices. Taste: Creamy and warm with molasses, wood notes, and apple. Spicy and hot on the end. 90/100.
Wonderful smell, golden brown color, caramel taste, alcohol content is just perfect and finish is long and smooth.

Smells like antiques, like wood cleaner, but pleasant. Some roasted grain and caramel too. Tastes like organ meats, dried fruit, nuts, but it somehow works. Spice on the front, dissappears, then shows up again at the back if the throat. Bold and smooth at the same time. 2/3/17
[LOOK] Amber, brown ale [NOSE] Candied cherry, Bananas foster, citrus rind [PALATE] Smoke, chickory root, ripe stone fruit, anise [FINISH] Long, hot, dry [MOUTHFEEL] Spicy, prickly
I love this American single malt. Full flavor, mild smoke, palatable sweetness. Overall a great whisky. Just wish it was at a slightly lower price point and easier to find!

Pralines, raisins, espresso w/ cream on the nose. A wonderful rich and creamy sweetness. More flavors become apparent as it opens up. Rich, fruity characters on the palate followed up by toasty, buttered popcorn that has been cooked just a bit too long. Unique! Like nothing I've had before. Too sweet and too expensive to purchase again
Texas' first single malt knows how to leave an impression. This is exceptional.
Fascinating malt.   Scotch beginnings with a bourbon finish.   Slight coffee liquor flavor.   One of the most unique whiskies around.
Probably overpriced but tasty. Very bold.
Perhaps not surprising for something this high proof, but it benefits greatly from being served on the rocks.

The first thing we need to address is just how laughable the color is: tawny, which means there's almost no doubt in my mind coloring was added here. Mind you, it's not impossible some of the sherry casks that were obviously used to age this whiskey played a large role in the color, since it clearly did so in the taste. There are elements of dates, old wood and nutmeg here, with the finish exhibiting notes of tobacco and pepper. The finish is quite nice and long, but I have to admit I have a difficult time enjoying this spirit.
Rich, sweet notes on the nose morph into dark chocolate , dried fruits and an incredibly plesant finish. My favorite American whisky.
Very malty. Fun. Better than expected.

I'm off to Texas in a couple of weeks for a road trip of Southern USA so got hold of a few Balcones samples to see if I should stock up on a few bottles whilst I'm there. Short answer...no...definate no. I'm with cask strength joe on this one. It looks seriously odd. Its quite a weird hazy orange in the glass sample bottle. I had it's sibling the Single Malt Rum Finish earlier in the week (come on Distiller please add the dozen or so whiskies I sent you to your site..it's been ages!) which came across quite artificial and the kitchen sink took a portion of my dram. Given that experience I started off with a smaller measure this time round. Its young, alcoholic and not much else to be honest. Bit of the standard drying wood, anise... Few drops of water didn't help. I'd give it a 2.5 and as its not quite at the 'nothing special but I'm happy to have a few drams' i.e a 3 level then it must be a 2 especially when the round $100 USD a bottle price is factored in.
A real surprisingly sweet and full whiskey. Interesting flavors.

Not a fan. Tastes like leather. 
Rating: 2.0

Wow. Brown sugar and rum-soaked raisins in the nose. Sweet, with more of the same on the palette, and a bit of caramel and dark chocolate in the finish, with a little sawdust appearing last. Adding some water reduces the heat and lets the flavors come out even more. Very impressive.

On the nose it's light fruit, the palate is full and chewy with vine-ripened peach, apricots, and some cinnamon and raisins. It finishes with a light warmth and maltiness. If you're looking for smoke, peat, or the briny sea you will not find it in this Texas single malt. It's overpriced in my opinion and at $60 I would rather have a Springbank 10 or Talisker 10.

Rich cocoa and cinnamon nose. Slightly hot with a subdued sweetness consisting of deep raisin, prune, and dried fig notes. I get cocoa again on the lengthy finish. This is a rich and challenging whisky!
Caramel nose, a sweet and bright taste with a generous mouth coat

Nose of grass, citrus, and dark honey - sweet and fragrant
Taste of dark cherry, tobacco and Ash
Nice mouth feel with lingering finish on the back of the tongue
It has a very interesting flavor profile but sadly not my dish.
Hickory smoked malted Easter egg.  Just a delicious Whiskey
Love this, reminds me of Bunnahabhain 12 - smoky, sweet, but even a bit richer. Amazing given it's aged for far shorter!
Still to young but WAY better than the blue corn.  Like eating a peach before it’s juicy and sweet....you know where it’s headed but it isn’t there yet

Nose: cinnamon, pecan, 
Taste: pecan, oatmeal, cinnamon, 

Added water... ok, but not great
A bit sweet, very smooth.  Excellent
Strong oak influence with some heavy fruit notes on the nose. Lots of fruit notes throughout on the taste
Is more like a scotch than a bourbon.  Big, rich and thick.  Has a great, fiery burnt wood, caramel finish.  A perfect fall whiskey...
batch SM17-9 Bronze color. Big barbecue nose, shoe leather.  The shoe leather notes continue on the palate, old wood taste. Very dry finish. Great with pepperoni pizza

Deep in the heart of Tejas! If you like scotch you’ll dig it, if not no issue.
Thick and syrupy malt madness, tingly spice on the finish. Competitive with Deerhammer and Stranahan’s. 
Me? I’ll stick with their Balcone Blue cuz corn is best served liquified!

What the hell just happened. I'm so confused right now. Fully expected this whiskey to be just all vanilla sweet. It is so much more... this whisky shape shifts and transforms from sip to sip. Complex yet easy.

Nose: malt, light cinnamon
Taste: caramel, barrel spice, 
Finish: oil, heat, pepper

This is Texas desert in a glass. It is beautiful
Lovely rich malt with a barrel spice finish. Notes of cloves, maple, and a hint of cinnamon.

One of the most interesting new American whiskeys. This whiskey made with Golden Promise barley malt and has a powerful nose. On the distillery tour they talked a bunch about flavor density and this definitely has it. Rich mouth feel and a long finish. A bit hot for it's proof but full of flavor.
Very good taste but strong. Great with a splash of water or let the ice melt a bit
wow. different like nothing I've ever tasted. but super intriguing and I want more!
Caramel and jonagold apples on the nose. Intense oak and malt notes on the taste as well. Slight bit of smoke despite being unpeated. Don't bother adding water.
Pear,Raisin, toffee, hint of spice. Love this!
I found it incredibly smooth and oily. Really enjoyed it after supper. My first American single malt. I did not have high expectations. This was shockingly great.
Strong kick due to the 106 proof but good taste for single malt.
pecan, vanilla, oily, full, Maple syrup, bite, quick finish, tried neat
Really big flavor and a great sipper.
Very good. Balanced between oak and the other flavors. Great sipping whiskey.

Nose: Cinnamon with some pecan sprinkled in. 

Palate: Caramel sweetness that coats the mouth, strong burnt toffee notes. Very rich and malty.

Overall a great Texas single malt. The richness might deter some from adding it to their regular stock, but as they say, a strong drink is for strong people.

Nose: honey, figs, leather, tobacco, black tea
Taste: dry red wine at first but quickly turns, lots of malt like a dark beer, strangely reminiscent of matzo bread, not much sweetness hints of the honey and figs that were more prominent on the nose
Finish: the malt and matzo notes linger with some spice like clove
After reading reviews: I didn’t get as much fruitiness but orange marmalade makes sense, at no point did it strike me as a 53% ABV
Peppery, damn peppery. Should proof interesting with chili
On the nose apples, banana bread, and oatmeal.  On the palate barley, oatmeal, banana bread, dark honey, a touch of cinnamon, and oak.  Unique but so rich I’m not sure how much I’ll reach for it.
Strong nose, cherry back. I lose th e middle
Rich full flavor of fruit. Long finish. Smooth flavor with a nice bit of bite.
This is my new favorite whisky

I’m admittedly a Balcones fan.
Long, spicy finish
Full rich flavor, oak, caramel, vanilla, and spice. This is a great pour and sets itself apart from other Tx whiskeys

Oak and carmel on the nose. Explosion of oak, ethanol heat, and spicy sweet grain in the mouth, then vanilla, nuts, earthy cereal and malt, and spice on the long finish. A big whisky that will open up with a little water/ice. It's also young, and would probably be a lot more interesting with more time in wood. Would help justify the hefty price too. Still, worth experiencing another unusual (in a good sense) product from an inventive distillery.
Lightly smokey, and sweet like a bourbon.
RICH & FULL BODIED. Very powerful but different taste than I am accustomed to with Scotch. I keep revisiting to develop my palate to this whiskey.

Poured neat into Glencairn at home.  Nose has caramel, Dr. Pepper, oak.  Nice.  Taste is a tad bitter, more spicy, more oak on the finish.  Touch thin.  Lingering spicy aftertaste.  Water opens up some vanilla and malt.  OK.  6/26/19

spicey and full body.

hints of carmel and dark malty/chocolate tastes.
Good flavors but not sure it’s as good as it’s rated

So, lots of wood aroma with a bit of burnt sugar.  Even more wood on the palate. If you made tea from oak chips I imagine this is what it would taste like. Lots of warming spice and pepper. Mouthfeel is very full, almost slick. Finish is long and tannic with hints of menthol.

I feels like in 2019 you can't drink whisky without being bombarded with these Texas whiskies.  So I'll save my views on some of the others and lets focus on Balcones which I believe is the most well distributed and it's not terribly priced either.  

Nose - fruity, cinnamon, toasted oak, and just a very nice funk I get on Amrut and Balcones, I have to assume it's perhaps a result of the speed aging.  

Taste - There's this berry and oak and cinnamon, and just perhaps just texas malt.  It's really different.  

I'm giving this is a solid 3.0.  I honestly don't really like where this one went, but it's such a clear high quality malt and so well made I can't score it any lower.
Delicious, sweet, smooth, and full. Worth it completely!

Probably closer to 1:1 on whiskey and water this time (not on purpose). Allowed some of the super muted flavor to come through like toasted bread and apple crisp. Super silky and a nice light gold color. Makes me think it'd do well in a carefully made whiskey soda.
Amazing on the nose. Smooth, but a touch of water opens it up nicely. Honey, bread, and jam on the palate with a little smokey goodness on the finish. Top notch; I see why this put them on the map.
Deep amber color that clings nicely to the glass. Cinnamon and cedar on the nose. Smells big and taste big - caramel and warm spice with a bit of heat. Great!
Tasting flight. This is hotter than I prefer but still has a good roasty flavor as the heat settles.

I love a good single malt and I love a good bourbon. What excites me about this whisky is the combination that makes Balcone's special and my favorite craft distillery. The nose hit me like fall. Woody, leathery, but sweet and tinged with crushed leaves. A fresh trip to Colombia forced the fruity and spicy notes into my favorite dessert of Bananos Calados. The flavor is very long and complex. Water opens it up, but the dram is still smooth for the heat at 106 Proof. So happy to see Balcone's offerings more widely available here in Arkansas.

Aroma: Wood, Fig, leather, & bananos calados (banana, cinnamon, orange, vanilla)
Flavor: Charred oak, dried fruits, spiced pear, & sweet cereal malt.
Aftertaste: Burnt sugar, clove, malt, & oak.
Body: Heavy, & silky
Smells like shoe polish. Tastes better than it smells but it’s overly sweet. Maple, apple pie. Not bad but wouldn’t be my daily drinker or go-to.

First impressions were very nice. I like the nose, I like the taste. However, as it opened up in the glass, it developed an anise note in the finish that started to take over, and I didn't particularly like. Overall good, but I'd rather not spend a lot of time with it.
This dram feels smoother. More vanilla and biscuit. Velvety. Pampering myself for working on graduate apps and grading.
Excellent, rich single malt. Wonderful sherry oak taste with nice woody, vanilla complexities. Dried fruit notes and a bit of tartness like skin of green apple. Excellent single malt!
I was impressed by this American whiskey
the butterscotch IS bigger in Texas. This might be the best ‘small batch’ American craft whisky out there. But beware - Balcones has some whiffs also
Honey and spice on the nose. Much of the same with some fruit on the palate. Nice and bold. I don’t know much about single malts, but I know I like putting this in my mouth.

Cinnamon bomb!

Tons of it on the nose and palate. Spice too on the palate. Tastes young but not too bitter. Pretty tasty.

There's lots of flavour packed in here, made into an interesting mix of Bourbon and malt styles. It's got the malty texture, cereal sweetness, and bits of brine from the malt, and lots of oak from the more American style. Unique! Some water brought out tons of tabacco and oak bitters for me. Not my favorite malt style, but it's good.
Rich stonefruit in the palate. Great barrel spice finish
This whisky is fantastic! Full of flavor and it smells just like it tastes. If Garrison Brothers made a single malt, it would taste like this. Smooth, viscous, lingering finish. I love it.
Wonderful. Tastes so soft and sweet for a single malt. Purchased at Whiskey Kitchen.
Very sweet on the nose with orange marmalade, pear, and spice notes. The taste is sweet up front followed promptly by spice, smoke, and a long warm finish from the 53% abv.

Rich and malty with a heavy dose of woody barrel and rum spice. Not much peat, if any, and an easy burn that finishes smooth. A drop or two of water brings out some caramel and some earthy tones. Damn fine.

Heavy fruit on the nose, palate. (A bit to much fruit, cherries, for me) Would say for me it’s a average bourbon at the moment. Will let it breath for a bit and come back and revisit to see if it changes the profile a bit.

Had some neat as an after dinner drink.   Was very disappointed with it.   I might have set my expectations too high.  it seemed like it was trying so hard to be Scotch and a bourbon but missed the mark on excelling in either one.  

It was interesting but would not order it again.

I hate to say it, because I’ve really heard a lot about what this distillery is doing for the Texas whiskey scene, but I (after 4 times going back over 6 months) DO NOT like this whiskey.

Nose: dark DARK fruit, barrel mustiness, the slight tinge of rotting leaves that I hate about the newest expressions of Highland Park 12. Just very old and musty tasting which is not what I look for in a malt heavy whiskey. 

Taste: Almost exactly the same as the nose. Raisins dominate with a slight sugariness. The mid pallet and finish I just don’t like. Not going to get into any tasting notes because I can barely stomach it.  Its just not my thing. 

Not faulting you for linking this whiskey. Sometimes people don’t understand why I like Islay peated Scotch so much and I think this whiskey is just the same. It’s a very acquired taste that I don’t think I’ll ever acquire the taste for. This is a just ones opinion, don’t let this sway your opinion by any means. Especially for all the accolades this distillery has won over the past few years.
Very interesting mix. Burnt sugar. Banana. Orange. Dried chilis and pepper. Not spicy but earthy tasting. Dry finish.

Aged wood aroma. Like grandmas attic, a barn or wood working shop. Rich thick mouth feel, with tastes of dark malt & raisins. Sweet notes at the front and slight heat on the backend. I say recommended and buy again!
Texas just messed with my mouth. (23 Advent19)
Nose of dark plums and wood gives way to burst of full bodied sweet  barreled full tongued toasted malt, corn, and spice. I cant stop drinking this!
I’m getting some sweetness, maybe cherry? Very enjoyable overall, happy to have picked it up.
Nice Woody start with a fruity nut flavor. This  will stay in my cabinet

VERYVERYVERY JAMMY. I think that whatever barreling they used in my specific bottle overpowered the Malt, but this dram definitely has its place on the shelf. IF you love sweet, dark fruit infused whiskey, you will love this, but in that way it seems 1 dimensional.  (I am not getting the wood or toast that other tasters are finding, just fruit, fruit, and more fruit.)
Dark fruit, raisin, honey notes. Even though it is 53% does not have the alcohol burn you would expert. Very solid whiskey. Thought I would need to add water, but quite enjoyed it neat.
Apple pie, cinnamon, pepper. Smoky caramel finish
Sweet, potpourri, baking cornbread nose;   fiery and spicy in ears, syrupy.

This is phenomenal! I get a surprisingly low amount of heat for the proof (53% for the 50mL sampler I got), with a lot of oak up front and a silky mouthfeel. The palate follows up with bitter chocolate and a bit of funk, with a very long finish of the chocolate and oak. I really enjoy this one for the depth of flavor and complexity, and could definitely see myself picking up a full bottle!
Phenomenal. First American single malt experience. Toffee, honey and baking spices all throughout. Toasty and smooth with a lot of baked fruit

Nose: brown sugar, caramel, vanilla, wood, light fruits - cherries , musty funk
Palette: black pepper, cinnamon, wood, vanilla, dark cherries
Finish: black pepper, cinnamon, long, oily, end in with caramel/brown sugar sweetness
Fantastic cinnamon and oaky vanilla nose, spicy wood in the palate and into the finish.

More of an American style single malt and because it is made in Texas, the Texas heat plays a big part in the profile. Big burst of alcohol burn and much heavier texture and flavor than you would get from a scotch. Maybe a little longer in the barrels and a slash of water will tame this wild beast.

This malt was pretty complex the more I sat with it and added a drop of water to explore.

N - sweet mulled wine flavors, some cinnamon, clove, cherry 

T - a combo of spice and sweet licorice. Carmel and butterscotch with hints of leather and dried apples

F - earthy was the first impression on the finish with some chocolate and spice. With water black paper became more present

I’ve loved trying the different varieties of American single malts and for the longest time I’ve struggled to get my hands on Balcones. Very glad to add this one to the collection! It is the perfect fall time dram. It is a bit more bourbony sweet than some other American malts I’ve tried but has way more complexity than a traditional bourbon would (IMO). Much like Del Bac to the Southwest and Westland to the Northwest, Balcones is exactly what you’d expect from a Texas whisky!
Really enjoy this. Subtly sweet but not overpowering. Strong but does not linger.
Tastes like sitting in the cabin of a combine. Not too shabby.
This whiskey reminds me of Foursquare Empery.  The flavor is bold, rich, sweet and the high ABV is noticeable.   A few drops of water opened a more sweet aroma.

Very interesting dram. It surpassed all my expectations. This is a single malt from Texas, that means malted barley and no corn at all, which is kinda a big deal because we are talking about a U.S. whisky. Nevertheless, as soon as you nose it, the first aroma notes are typical bourbon notes. 

Bottled at 53%abv, with a beautiful chesnut color. Amazingly thick and slow legs on the glencairn. 

So many things going on the nose
There is definitively some bourbonish/jack daniels profile, i guess to impress U.S. drinkers.

On the nose: Banana, Vanilla escense, Vanilla ice cream, White chocolate, Maple syrup, Sherry sweetness, Prunes.It sure feels like its going to grow into red fruits but it doesn't. Amazingly sweet and appealing.

On the palate is also a good dram, but not as incredible as the nose. Oily, Cake burnt, Spicy: mild pepper. Some Sherry. Oaky. Sour prunes. A little smoke, woody smoke.
Mostly sour and smoky. Sour sherry. 

Finish is medium, a little hot, ashy. Ginger spice stays a little longer. Malty. Cloying sugar.

Overall it feels like they use a virgin american oak barrel but some sherry must have been used also. The only way banana and vanilla are that strong in the aroma is by using a new barrel of american oak. The dried fruits/sherry notes are mostly on the palate. Great dram, totally recommended: my score for it is a solid 88 over 100 but it surely feels like more. Maybe a 4.5 would do it justice.

Nose: sweet caramel with an almost praline tone. There is something rich and spicy hiding underneath 
Taste: toasted bread upfront into a well rounded spiciness that gently mellows
Finish: long and oily that comes back around to toast

I was a scotch drinker before becoming a Bourbon drinker. I now prefer Bourbon so this ended up being a disappointment. I does not compare to Scotch. With that said, it’s not terrible. I get dried fruit on the nose and spice on the palate. Decent finish too. It’s kind of in no mans land between Scotch and American Whiskey.
Hints of cherry and an amazing sweet malt finish.

Nose- green apples, oak
Taste- starts off sweet with apple then moved to dark fruit (raisin) and adds cinnamon, grain, and lot of heat
Has great mouthfeel and beautiful color. My first balcones whiskey and very impressed by the complexity of flavors.
Delicious nose. Good texture with loads of cinnamon red hots. Very interesting whiskey for someone looking for something different.
Notes of maple and pecan, and the perfect kick on the finish. This is quickly becoming my absolute favorite.
I get maple on the nose, sweet taste with spice.

Since Balcones has a dozen different versions of this. What I had was the Pot Distilled.
At first taste it was dark fruit raisins and fig newton. Sweet brown sugar cinnamon. But left me with a slight metallic feel at the end which reminded me of spraying the back of my throat with phenol or maybe oral lidocaine.
Reminds me of banana bread. Very interesting drink.
Very interesting product here. I’m a barrel proof guy but this is ‘spicy’. Lots of wood flavor and great mouth feel
Nice. Fruit strips gum. In all the right ways.

The nose has tart ale, but also some baking spice and maple syrup that combines with golden raisins to be a bit sickly and flat. The tartness has a bit of a woody yeasty scent. There is definitely an ale flavor here. It's surprisingly tart in a way that is a bit jarring, but there is also some sweetness from the baking spices and cinnamon, as well as some maple sweetness. The alcohol is harsh and while there are some interesting flavors, the whole thing tastes a bit young. It does have a distinctly malty flavor to it that I appreciate though. There's a decent amount of smoke too, but it kind of stands as its own flavor and exacerbates the harshness (though it is effective at balancing the sweetness). There's something a bit distinctly bourbony going on here somehow and unfortunately that creates a sharply bitter, slightly tart flavor.

Flaviar sample. My expectations were high. I have researched Texas Whisky and wanted to start with this one. Nose is very unusual... a big hit of banana, pear and orange. Palate is loud but very good: mild sweetness, spicy, caramel, wood. I need more experience with this style

How to address the elephant in the (bar)room that is Texas whiskey? I hadn't planned on it, but then I ran across this 5 cl miniature at my favorite liquor store. I just saw a big number '1' emblazoned on the label with the words, "Texas Single Malt".  Naturally, this peaked my curiosity.  Because as everyone knows, California is number one (.. and done).  I decided to include this stylish, glass usurper with my purchase. On with the particulars.  Nice aroma with cinnamon, dark spice, and cherry.  (I don't take much stock in the nose.  As far as I'm concerned it's perfume and distilled stuff I don't want to read about.) The initial palate is a burst of cinnamon and red licorice.  Follow on sips emphasize a cinnamon red hots note.  The finish is a tad drying, with soft leather and rafter oak.  A half teaspoon of water opens up the aroma with an undertone of toffee or caramel, lying beneath the dominant cinnamon note.  With water on the palate, I detect a borderline sherry influence, but it is held in check by the cinnamon wagon as its base.  Still, no sulphuric nastiness.  (That's more than I can say for many single malt scotches.)  Despite the ABV of 53%, there's surprisingly little prickle.  This will make for a delightful winter whiskey, no doubt.  But the over-the-top cinnamon note drowns out the other whiskey nerdy things I could've liked about it.  In any event, I'm impressed with what Balcones has accomplished under the conditions that is Texas heat. I'd imagine that must take serious skills and/or b---s. This single malt definitely has a time and place for an occasional dram.  However, there's just not enough here for me to warrant a full bottle purchase.  To wrap things up, while there's a 'Woah' aspect in drinking this, there isn't enough 'Giddy Up' to keep at it.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."

Balcones seems like the people that run it thought to themselves “why don’t we make the best whiskey”...and that was it. The stats sheets read like a whiskey connoisseur’s dream distillery. Their whiskey is high proof, they age and finish them in all sort of styles of barrels. They age the whiskey as long as the Texas heat will allow. They use golden promise barley which is the best...apparently.  They are always experimenting and coming out with new bottles.  They focus on the details. This Texas Single Malt version is a must if you like malt whiskey. Let it be the gateway into Balcones distillery. A true example of how Texans do whiskey.
